Homage to Buddha Dharma Ke-tou
Next, pay homage to the great canon of the twelve divisions of the Buddhist canon.
Bow in respect to the great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas of the ten directions.
Take refuge in the immeasurable and boundless great bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas of the worlds of the ten directions.
Pay homage to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all the sages.
Take refuge in the immeasurable and boundless pratyekabuddhas.
After paying homage to the Three Jewels, next repent.
Disciples!
Having already repented the afflictive hindrances and having already repented the karmic hindrances, the remaining karmic hindrances are now to be confessed in order.
The sÅ«tras say:

'When the retribution of karma arrives, it is not in the sky, the ocean, or in the mountains and rocks, nor is there any other place to escape and avoid retribution, except through the power of repentance, which can truly eliminate it.'
How do we know this?

When the five signs of decline appeared to Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra, he was terrified and wholeheartedly turned to the Three Jewels, and the signs of death immediately disappeared and he extended his heavenly lifespan.
There are many such examples clearly stated in the scriptures and teachings, so we know that repentance can truly eliminate misfortune.
However, ordinary people, if not guided by good friends, will commit all kinds of evil, and when their life is about to end, the evil signs of hell will all appear before them.
At that time, remorse and fear will come upon them, but it will be too late to cultivate goodness. Only then will they regret not having done so earlier, but what use is regret at that point?

Calamities and misfortunes await in different places, and you will be alone and helpless, far away from your loved ones. You will only proceed forward, entering a great cauldron, your body and mind crushed, your spirit in agony. At such a time, how can you hope to perform a single prostration or repentance?
All of you!

Do not be complacent about your youth, wealth, or power, lazy, indolent, negligent, or self-indulgent. Once the suffering of death arrives, it makes no distinction between old and young, poor and rich, noble and humble. All will be extinguished, and it will come suddenly, without warning.
Life is impermanent, like morning dew. Although the out-breath may remain, the in-breath is difficult to guarantee. How can you not repent?

Moreover, once the five messengers arrive and the demon of impermanence suddenly strikes, even those in their prime cannot escape. At that time, what connection will you have with your luxurious mansion?
How can your fine carriages and horses follow you? Your spouse and relatives will no longer be your kin. The seven precious treasures and ornaments will become someone else's playthings.
Based on this, it can be said that all karmic retributions in the world are like illusions and transformations.
Although the heavens are blissful, they will eventually decay and perish. When the lifespan is exhausted, the soul and spirit fall into the three evil paths. Therefore, the Buddha said to Subhadra:

'Your teacher Udraka Ramaputra had sharp faculties, was wise, and was able to subdue afflictions. He reached the state of neither perception nor non-perception, but upon death, he was reborn as a flying leopard in the animal realm, let alone the others.
' Therefore, it is known that those who have not yet realized the holy fruit will all continue to transmigrate and experience the evil destinies.
If one is not careful, suddenly one day one will personally encounter this matter, and it will be too late to regret it.

Or, like now, when one is convicted and goes to the public office, it is already a small suffering. The mind is agitated and frightened, and relatives seek help in a hundred ways. The various sufferings of hell are millions and billions of times worse than this, and cannot be compared.
All of you!
Our sins from going through eons together are like Mount Sumeru. How can we hear this and remain calm, without fear, alarm, or terror?
Allowing this spirit to again undergo this suffering is truly lamentable.
Therefore, disciples!
Transporting this sincere heart, with utmost sincerity we take refuge in the Buddha.

We pay homage to Buddha Meritorious Flower in the East, to Buddha Light Honored One in the South, to Buddha Boundless Life in the West, to Buddha Meritorious Victor in the North, to Buddha Sumeru in the Southeast, to Buddha Unimpeded Benefit in the Southwest, to Buddha Good and Wonderful of the World in the Northwest, to Buddha Superior Incense Meru in the Northeast, to Buddha Taming Intentions Surpassing All Flowers in the Nadir, and to Buddha Pure Wheel Banner in the Zenith. We take refuge in the Thus-Come Ones of the ten directions, throughout the realm of space, in the Three Jewels.
Disciples!
From beginningless time until today, the heaviest of karmic hindrances is none other than the AvÄ«ci Hell, as explained in the sÅ«tras. Now I will briefly describe its characteristics.

This hell is surrounded by seven layers of iron walls, and seven layers of iron nets cover above. Below there are seven layers of sword forests and immeasurable fierce fires. It is 84,000 yojanas long and wide.

The bodies of the sinners fill the entire space, and due to their karmic actions they do not obstruct each other. The upper fire penetrates the lower, and the lower fire penetrates the upper, passing through the east, west, south, and north. It is like a fish in a frying pan, with the fat completely used up. The suffering of the sinners here is also like this.
At the four gates of the city there are four huge copper dogs, each forty yojanas long and wide, with sharp teeth and claws, and eyes like lightning.
There are also innumerable iron-beaked birds that fly and soar, pecking at the flesh of the sinners. The ox-headed jail guards have the appearance of rÄká¹£asas, and have nine tails like iron forks.

There are also eight-headed ones, with eighteen horns on their heads, and sixty-four eyes. From each eye, iron pellets are shot out, burning the flesh of the sinners. When they roar in anger, the sound is like thunder.

There are also innumerable natural swords and wheels that descend from the sky, entering through the crown of the sinners' heads and exiting through their feet. The sinners' pain pierces to the bone marrow, and the suffering cuts to the liver and heart.
Thus, for innumerable years they experience various sufferings, unable to find life or death.
Such retributions, I now all bow my head in shame and reveal with a sincere mind to repent.
The other hells, the sword mountain and tree hell, where the body and head fall off, I repent of the retribution for sins;
The hells of boiling cauldrons and burning charcoal, the karmic retribution of being boiled and roasted, we repent.

The hells of iron beds and copper pillars, the karmic retribution of being burned, we repent.ğŸ”½The hells of knives, wheels, and fiery chariots, the karmic retribution of being split and crushed, we repent.
The hells of pulling out tongues and plowing with plows, the karmic retribution of extreme pain, we repent.

The hells of swallowing iron pellets and pouring molten copper into the mouth, the karmic retribution of the five internal organs dissolving, we repent.ğŸ”½The hells of iron pestles and iron grinders, the karmic retribution of bones and flesh being ground to dust, we repent.

The hells of black ropes and iron nets, the karmic retribution of limbs being separated, we repent.ğŸ”½The hells of the river of ashes and boiling excrement, the karmic retribution of distress and suffocation, we repent.

The hells of salty water and cold water, the karmic retribution of skin splitting open and freezing naked, we repent.ğŸ”½The hells of tigers, wolves, hawks, and dogs, the karmic retribution of harming each other, we repent.
The hells of weapons, claws, and beaks, the karmic retribution of grabbing, stabbing, and slashing each other, we repent.
The hells of fire pits, the karmic retribution of being roasted, we repent.
The Two Stones Smashing Hell, the retribution of shattered bones and body, we repent;ğŸ”½The Black Ear Gathering Hell, the retribution of being cut apart, we repent.
The Dark Meat Mountain Hell, the retribution of being chopped up, we repent;ğŸ”½The Sawing and Nailed Body Hell, the retribution of being cut off, we repent;
The Iron Rod Hanging Upside Down Hell, the retribution of being slaughtered, we repent;
The Burning Hot Screaming Hell, the retribution of vexation and resentment, we repent;
Between the great and small iron mountains, the long night of darkness, not recognizing the three luminaries, we repent.

The hells of A-pa-pa, A-sa-sa, A-ta-ta, and A-luo-luo, these eight cold and eight hot hells, in each hell there are 84,000 subsidiary hells as attendants. The suffering and pain in these hells are beyond description.
Homage to the Buddha!
Those who are in these hells now may have been our parents from beginningless time, or all our relatives. After we die, we may also fall into such hells.

Today, with a sincere and repentant heart, we bow our heads and kowtow to the Buddhas in the ten directions and the great bodhisattvas, seeking their compassion and repentance, to eradicate all karmic hindrances.

May the disciples, by the merit of repenting of the retributions of hells and so forth, wish to be born in every life in the compassionate buddhas who save the suffering of sentient beings, immediately destroy the iron city of AvÄ«ci Hell, and all become pure lands without the name of evil paths.

In the remaining hells, all the instruments of suffering become conditions for happiness. The mountains of swords and forests of swords transform into jeweled forests. In the cauldrons of boiling water and furnaces of burning charcoal, lotus flowers are born. The ox-headed guards abandon their violence and all give rise to compassion without any evil thoughts. The sentient beings in hell attain liberation from the fruits of suffering and no longer create causes. They equally experience happiness like the third dhyÄna heaven, and at once give rise to the unsurpassed aspiration for enlightenment.
Baota previously entered an iron fire house hell.
Why is it called the iron house hell?

The hell is thirty-four yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls, covered by an iron net, and has four iron corners. A great wind blows fiercely towards the city, the iron city shakes, and fire naturally emerges, burning all over the hell.
There are also iron spikes as sharp as swords, suspended in the air, making a loud rumbling sound like thunder. The spikes descend and pierce the bodies of the offenders.
There is a large iron bed more than forty steps in circumference, surrounded by fire houses, enveloping the bodies of the offenders, covering the entire bed, with all the retributions unobstructed.
At that time, in the western gate, there were countless offenders who cried out, saying:
What sins have we committed to enter this place?
Beating their entire bodies, stumbling and rolling around, crying and wailing, they refused to move forward.

The horse-headed rÄká¹£asa grabbed an iron clamp with his hand, clamped it against his chest, and threw him into the prison. Where the clamp was placed, smoke and flames came out together. The prison guard yaká¹£a hooked him with a large iron hook, aiming at his head, and dragged him into an iron fire house.
The house was surrounded by raging flames. The power of karma blew the criminal's body around. He climbed onto a bed and lay down.
There was a large poisonous snake with scales and spikes all over its body. It entered through his mouth and came out from below.
There was also an iron bird that pecked at his heart, pulling out his heart and intestines.
Such suffering was unbearable. In one day and night, he experienced countless punishments. He could not find life or death.

After countless kalpas, he was able to escape. After leaving the hells, he became an animal, pulling a plow and carrying heavy burdens to repay his past debts. For hundreds of lifetimes and thousands of lifetimes, there was no rest.
Baota asked the horse-headed rÄká¹£asa:
What sins did these criminals commit to suffer such torment?
The horse-headed rÄká¹£asa replied:

These monks received the pure precepts of the Buddha but did not uphold them. They slept in the houses of laypeople without being invited, and because of this they gave rise to lustful thoughts, defiling pure monks and nuns, and stealing from the saá¹ƒgha.

Because of these offenses, they fell into this hell. Later, when reborn as humans, they will fall into the five heinous crimes, be poor and lowly, with tattered clothes not covering their bodies, and live in the open without a home of their own.
When Baodala heard this, he wept and said:
How is it that those who have left the world are bound by worldly affairs?
Having attained the gate of liberation, they are instead oppressed by desire?
